scenes.plot_segment: A narrator recaps previous events, highlighting Meredith Grey’s secret romantic relationship with her attending, Dr. Derek Shepherd, and the complications it brings since he is her boss. Scenes show Meredith and Derek discussing the risks of their affair, with Meredith expressing uncertainty about continuing due to the professional consequences and Dr. Miranda Bailey’s awareness of their relationship. The recap also covers George O’Malley being teased by Cristina Yang and Izzie Stevens about his feelings for Meredith, which he denies. Meredith is shown meeting with a lawyer about her mother Ellis Grey’s advancing Alzheimer’s disease and being asked to sign over her mother’s estate, leaving Meredith visibly shocked. Brief, tense moments between Meredith and Derek are shown, including an awkward coffee interaction, underscoring the strain in their relationship and the challenges Meredith faces at work and in her personal life.

Meredith Grey narrates about procrastination and the fear that keeps people from making decisions, referencing Benjamin Franklin’s advice against putting things off. As she rushes into the hospital, running late, she calls out to Cristina Yang to save her spot. In the locker room, Cristina, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev discuss Meredith’s tardiness and tease George about his supposed feelings for Meredith, which he denies. Cristina insists they shouldn’t wait for Meredith, joking that she’s not her mother or boyfriend. The conversation shifts to George’s reluctance to ask anyone out, with Cristina and Izzie pressing him while Alex makes sarcastic remarks. Meredith arrives, flustered, and Cristina confronts her about avoiding her after Dr. Miranda Bailey saw Meredith and Derek Shepherd together. Meredith admits the situation is complicated, especially now that Bailey is ignoring her. The narration continues, focusing on the fear of failure, pain, and rejection, as the interns prepare to start their day.

Meredith Grey arrives late at Seattle Grace Hospital and is immediately approached by Dr. Derek Shepherd, who confronts her about avoiding him since Dr. Miranda Bailey discovered their relationship. Meredith admits she has been avoiding Derek and points out that she is late for work. Derek tries to discuss the complications of their secret relationship, especially now that Bailey knows and is not speaking to Meredith. Meredith expresses her discomfort with being the intern involved with an attending and the resulting tension with Bailey. Derek asks if Meredith wants him to be a better man and end things between them. Meredith hesitates, first saying yes, then no, clearly conflicted. She ultimately walks away, insisting she is late, while Derek tells her to take her time and think about what she wants.

Meredith Grey and Dr. Derek Shepherd share a brief, intimate moment outside the hospital, with Meredith remarking that being late was worth it to see him. As Meredith hurries inside, Cristina Yang confronts her about avoiding her since Dr. Miranda Bailey caught Meredith and Derek together. Meredith confides that Bailey is now giving her the silent treatment, making her feel isolated. Cristina reassures Meredith that Bailey is unlikely to tell anyone about the affair but warns that if their relationship becomes public, Derek could be humiliated and lose professional opportunities. Meredith, feeling the weight of the situation, decides she needs to end things with Derek. Cristina bluntly tells Meredith to stop complaining, insisting that nothing good comes from sleeping with an attending. Their conversation is cut short when Bailey arrives and sternly reprimands both Meredith and Cristina for being late, making it clear she expects better from them as interns.

Dr. Miranda Bailey leads the interns—Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev—into Annie Connors’ hospital room, instructing them to maintain professionalism. Annie, a 43-year-old woman with a massive tumor pressing against her diaphragm, greets the group with humor, making light of her age and weight. Alex presents Annie’s case, detailing her symptoms and the tumor’s impact on her breathing. Dr. Preston Burke enters to oversee the case as Alex continues the presentation. Annie flirts with Alex, requesting that he accompany her to her scheduled CT scan because she finds him attractive. After leaving the room, the interns discuss the extraordinary size of Annie’s tumor and speculate about its weight, expressing amazement and curiosity. Bailey cautions the interns that Annie’s upcoming surgery will require most of the hospital’s surgical staff, so they must be especially attentive to their other patients during this time.

Dr. Miranda Bailey leads Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev into Mr. LaVangie’s room, where Meredith presents his case: a 63-year-old man with advanced Parkinson’s disease admitted for pain management. The group discusses treatment options, including deep brain stimulation (DBS), but Mr. LaVangie is hesitant about undergoing brain surgery. His daughter, present at the bedside, pleads with Meredith to help convince her father, expressing her hope that he will be well enough to attend her upcoming wedding. Dr. Derek Shepherd enters, reviews the case, and assigns Meredith to prep Mr. LaVangie for the DBS procedure and assist in surgery. Bailey instructs the remaining interns to find other tasks, making it clear she expects them to stay busy and out of trouble.

Dr. Miranda Bailey corners Dr. Derek Shepherd in the hospital hallway, making it clear that she is aware of his relationship with Meredith Grey. Bailey firmly warns Derek not to show any favoritism toward Meredith, stating that if she observes any special treatment, she will keep Meredith out of the operating room for a month. Derek attempts to defend Meredith’s abilities and insists that his decisions are based on her skills as a surgeon, but Bailey remains resolute and unyielding, emphasizing the consequences of any perceived bias.

Izzie Stevens gently prepares Annie Connors for her CT scan, explaining the procedure and assuring Annie that she will stay close by throughout. Annie, maintaining her upbeat attitude despite her condition, expresses confidence and jokes to lighten the mood. Izzie checks if Annie is ready, and Annie gives her consent to proceed, trusting Izzie’s reassurance as they move forward with the scan.

In the radiology viewing room, Alex Karev and another intern examine Annie Connors’ CT scan, openly marveling at the enormous size of her tumor. Alex expresses disbelief that Annie allowed it to grow so large, speculating that she must have been terrified of hospitals. The other intern dismisses this explanation, making a harsh remark that Annie is “sick” and “warped” for letting her condition progress so far. Their conversation is inadvertently broadcast into the CT room via a live microphone, allowing Annie to overhear their insensitive comments about her illness.

Annie’s mother, Mrs. Connors, sits with Dr. Miranda Bailey and intern Izzie Stevens, explaining that Annie was first thought to be gaining weight, but as the tumor grew, Annie became increasingly afraid to seek medical attention, especially after losing several family members in hospitals. Mrs. Connors says Annie only realized how sick she was the previous night when she struggled to breathe, prompting her to call 911. Dr. Bailey gently explains that the tumor has grown so large it is compressing Annie’s lungs, which is why she could no longer breathe.

Dr. Bailey informs Annie Connors’s mother that she should have brought Annie to the hospital much sooner, given the severity of her tumor. Bailey then moves on to check on Mr. LaVangie, a patient with Parkinson’s disease. Mr. LaVangie’s daughter approaches Meredith Grey, asking if she can help convince her father to consider deep brain stimulation surgery so he might be well enough to walk her down the aisle at her wedding. She explains her hopes for the procedure and her fear of losing her father to his illness. Meredith empathizes, sharing that she understands what it’s like to watch a parent decline, and promises to do what she can to help.

Dr. Preston Burke leads a surgical planning meeting with Dr. Miranda Bailey and several interns, including Cristina Yang and George O’Malley, to discuss Annie Connors’ massive abdominal tumor. They debate the best surgical approach—whether to begin from the spine or the anterior side—carefully weighing the risk of paralysis against the risk of Annie dying on the table. Cristina questions whether Annie truly wants to live, given how long she avoided seeking treatment, while Bailey counters that fear can make people delay care and that Annie deserves a chance regardless. Burke emphasizes Annie’s age—43—and insists that they owe her every effort. The team agrees on a surgical plan, determined to give Annie the best possible outcome.

Meredith approaches Dr. Derek Shepherd to discuss Mr. LaVangie’s case, asking if he is a good candidate for deep brain stimulation (DBS) surgery. Derek confirms that Mr. LaVangie is medically eligible, but points out that the patient is adamantly against undergoing brain surgery. Meredith, motivated by the pleas of Mr. LaVangie’s daughter and her own empathy, wants to persuade him to reconsider, but Derek insists that it is not their place to pressure the patient. Their disagreement becomes tense, with Derek telling Meredith not to scrub in on the case, making it clear that her personal feelings are interfering with her professional judgment. Meredith is frustrated by Derek’s decision and the boundaries he is drawing between them, both professionally and personally.

Dr. Miranda Bailey meets with Annie Connors and her mother to discuss the upcoming surgery to remove Annie’s massive tumor. Bailey explains the significant risks involved, emphasizing that while there is always a chance of death during such a complex operation, without surgery, Annie’s prognosis is grim and she will die soon. Annie, anxious and still hurt by the insensitive comments she overheard from Alex Karev and the other interns during her CT scan, asks Bailey directly if she is going to die. Bailey answers honestly about the risks. Annie’s mother insists that Annie must have the surgery, but Annie refuses to proceed if Alex is present in the operating room, explaining that setting this boundary is how she can cope with the situation. Bailey listens to Annie’s concerns and agrees to her condition, assuring her that Alex will not be involved in her surgery.

Miranda Bailey confronts Alex Karev after Annie Connors overhears Alex and the other interns making insensitive remarks about her tumor during her CT scan, as the microphone was accidentally left on. Annie, hurt by the comments, specifically requests that Alex not be present during her surgery. Bailey reprimands Alex for his lack of professionalism and bans him from the OR for a week, despite his protests that he didn’t realize the mic was on. Bailey assigns another intern to scrub in with Cristina Yang for Annie’s surgery. As Annie is prepped for the operation, she jokes self-deprecatingly about being the “fat, nasty tumor lady,” but then expresses guilt and shame for letting her condition worsen for so long. When Cristina gently asks why she waited, Annie explains her deep fear of hospitals, stemming from losing several family members there. George O’Malley, trying to empathize, shares his own struggle with fear—specifically, his inability to confess his feelings to his roommate—but Annie is unimpressed by the comparison, highlighting the difference between their fears.

Cristina Yang and Meredith Grey talk privately about the growing perception among the interns that Meredith is receiving special treatment because of her secret relationship with Dr. Derek Shepherd. Cristina reassures Meredith that she has earned her opportunities but warns her that if the others find out about the affair, they will resent her. Meredith, feeling the pressure and guilt, insists she needs to end things with Derek. Alex Karev interrupts, eager to scrub in on Annie Connors’ surgery, but Cristina and Meredith dismiss his request, clearly preoccupied. As Alex leaves, Izzie Stevens and Cristina joke about stabbing Alex with a fork, venting their frustration with him. George O’Malley joins the group, and the conversation shifts to Derek’s behavior toward Meredith. George, trying to lighten the mood, invites everyone out for drinks after their shift, but the tension among the interns remains.

George checks on Mr. Harper, examining his back and responding to the patient’s request to leave the call button within reach. He then visits Mr. LaVangie, who is still refusing to consent to deep brain stimulation surgery for his Parkinson’s disease. George gently asks if he’s reconsidered, but Mr. LaVangie, frustrated by the repeated questioning, firmly declines and insists that it’s his life and his brain. His daughter, present at the bedside, pleads with him to try the surgery so he can be well enough to attend her wedding, but he remains adamant. Meredith arrives and tries to persuade Mr. LaVangie by emphasizing that his choices affect his daughter’s life as well as his own, urging him to consider the surgery for her sake. Mr. LaVangie listens but remains conflicted, while his daughter looks to Meredith for hope.

In the operating room, Dr. Preston Burke instructs Cristina Yang and another intern that they will be responsible for retracting Annie Connors’ massive tumor throughout the lengthy surgery. Meanwhile, Dr. Derek Shepherd is informed by Meredith Grey that Mr. LaVangie has finally agreed to undergo deep brain stimulation, but only if the procedure happens today. Meredith stresses the urgency, warning Derek that Mr. LaVangie might back out if given the chance to leave. Recognizing the risk, Derek decides to proceed with the surgery immediately.

Meredith approaches Dr. Bailey in an attempt to explain that she was unaware Derek was her attending when they first met. Bailey, clearly frustrated, cuts her off and tells Meredith that she doesn't care about her personal life, but is upset by how Meredith's relationship with Derek is disrupting her day and the surgical program. Bailey warns Meredith that as word spreads among the other interns and staff, they will resent her, making things more difficult for everyone involved. Bailey makes it clear that Meredith’s choices have consequences for the entire team and advises her to consider how her actions are affecting those around her.

Alex Karev and Izzie Stevens are assigned to prep Annie Connors for her upcoming surgery, but both are frustrated at being excluded from the operating room. They joke sarcastically about performing the procedure themselves in the stairwell, venting their disappointment. Izzie leaves to change, still upset about being banned from the OR after the incident with Annie overhearing the interns’ insensitive comments. Another intern, excited to be included in surgery, expresses gratitude for the opportunity. In the operating room, Cristina Yang and another intern are tasked with holding up Annie’s massive tumor for hours, their backs straining from the effort. Dr. Preston Burke meticulously cauterizes bleeders and requests additional units of blood as the team works to manage the tumor’s complex vascular involvement. George O’Malley, distracted while retracting, is sharply reprimanded by Dr. Burke for losing focus. The surgical team presses on, determined to continue the difficult operation despite mounting fatigue.

Derek Shepherd performs deep brain stimulation surgery on Mr. LaVangie, with Meredith Grey and Izzie Stevens assisting in the OR. As Derek prepares to drill into Mr. LaVangie’s skull, he reassures the patient, who lightens the mood by joking that if anything goes wrong, he’ll blame Meredith. During the procedure, Derek asks Mr. LaVangie to mimic his hand movements to ensure the electrode placement is correct. The surgery is successful, and Mr. LaVangie, now in good spirits, jokes that if Meredith doesn’t marry Derek, he will. Meredith and Izzie share a relieved smile as Derek thanks Meredith for her help.

Meredith confronts Derek about the complications their relationship is causing at work, expressing frustration that his actions—whether showing her favoritism or being dismissive—are making her look bad in front of their colleagues. She insists that he cannot treat her differently because of their personal involvement and asserts that she can take care of herself, though she admits she feels trapped by the situation. Derek acknowledges the difficulty and tells Meredith she did excellent work that day. Meredith stands her ground, making it clear she wants to be treated like any other intern, regardless of their relationship.

Mr. Harper, a post-operative heart patient, suddenly goes into cardiac distress as his blood pressure plummets. Cristina Yang and Izzie Stevens are the only interns present, and with no attending physician immediately available, they quickly call for help. Mrs. Harper is urgently escorted out of the room by a nurse as the crisis escalates. Cristina, remaining calm under pressure, instructs Izzie to perform an emergency bedside thoracotomy—cracking Mr. Harper’s chest open to access his heart—despite Izzie’s fear and lack of experience with the procedure. Guided step-by-step by Cristina and a resident over the phone, Izzie makes the incision, reaches into the chest cavity, and manually removes a blood clot obstructing the heart. She then massages Mr. Harper’s heart until his pulse returns, successfully stabilizing him as the medical team arrives to take over.

In the operating room, Dr. Preston Burke leads the surgical team as they continue the complex removal of Annie Connors’ massive abdominal tumor. Cristina Yang and George O’Malley assist, with George tasked to help retract the tumor and apply pressure as the team struggles to control severe blood loss. The tumor is more invasive than anticipated, entwined with fragile artery walls that begin to tear, causing Annie’s condition to deteriorate rapidly. Burke urgently calls for more blood, and the team works frantically to stabilize her, but the bleeding becomes uncontrollable. Despite their coordinated efforts and repeated attempts to repair the damaged vessels, Annie goes into cardiac arrest. Burke and the team attempt resuscitation, but Annie dies on the table, leaving the surgical team exhausted and devastated by the loss after their prolonged effort.

Despite the surgical team’s exhaustive efforts, Dr. Burke and the interns are unable to save Annie Connors as uncontrollable bleeding overwhelms them in the operating room. Dr. Miranda Bailey solemnly calls the time of death at 11:42, and the team stands in stunned silence, devastated by the loss after their hours-long struggle.

Meredith narrates about the dangers of hesitation and the inevitability of making mistakes, reflecting on proverbs about time and fear. In the aftermath of the emergency bedside surgery, Izzie is visibly shaken, doubting her actions. Cristina reassures Izzie, telling her she saved Mr. Harper’s life and did what was necessary under pressure. Meredith’s narration continues, emphasizing that sometimes people need to experience things firsthand and make their own choices, even if it means risking failure.

Cristina, exhausted and frustrated after spending twelve hours holding up Annie Connors’ massive tumor during surgery, vents to Meredith that she is done doing favors for her, especially after losing Annie on the operating table. Meredith, still reeling from the loss and the ongoing tension with Derek Shepherd, discusses their complicated relationship with him. They question what their relationship means and whether it needs to be defined, acknowledging the risks and complications it brings to their professional lives. Despite their uncertainty, Meredith and Derek decide to lock the door to Derek’s office and be together, choosing to face the consequences rather than continue avoiding each other.

George approaches Alex in the hallway and asks if he has seen Meredith. Alex, aware of Meredith’s secret relationship with Dr. Derek Shepherd, tells George that Meredith is “off the market,” hinting at her involvement with someone. George, oblivious to Meredith and Derek’s affair, insists that he would know if Meredith were seeing anyone since they are roommates, denying any possibility of her having a secret relationship.

As dawn approaches, Meredith Grey narrates about the necessity of confronting fears and embracing the possibility of failure rather than avoiding risks. Derek Shepherd finds Meredith outside the hospital and quietly invites her to watch the sunrise over the ferry boats. Standing together, Meredith admits she remembers why she loves ferry boats, a small moment of clarity amid her emotional turmoil. As they watch the sun rise, Meredith’s narration concludes that even the greatest failure is better than never having tried at all, underscoring her resolve to face the uncertainties in her life and relationships. Derek thanks her, and they share a quiet, hopeful moment before the day begins.
